38019680.review:
An excellent puzzle platformer with Paper Mario aesthetics mixed in with dark, morbid humor. 
I wasn't expecting much going into this, but I ended up having a ton of fun playing it. 

The maps are decently sized, and it's filled to the brim with a vast assortment of fun, quirky npcs you can interact with. 
The gameplay revolves around you aiding said npcs by finding items they need in order to progress.
One of the main selling points of the game is that the whole world is made of paper and stickers. You can peel parts of the map to reveal hidden objects or characters, and you can even slap one sticker onto another to get through a puzzle. There's also the ability to read minds which always leads to some silly dialogue. 

Overall, I loved this and found this to be a pretty enjoyable and memorable experience.

36546202.review:
It’s not bad. Just disappointing.

[h1]Story:[/h1]
You’re a dude who has an alien stuck in his brain and now he has telekinesis and mind reading and a bad guy is after the alien. The story is pretty simple and overall, it progresses at a good pace. Each level has a mini story and an overall mission. Each character you interact with is a piece of this overall mission and you do the standard adventure game logic of “get item, place item, reward”.

However, the characters are kind of boring. Each one only has one trait and they usually disappear after one area so they don’t feel interesting. Each one spurts 1 or 2 lines and except for one joke referencing the godfather, I didn’t laugh at all. I didn’t know much about these characters and I didn’t want to.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
It’s an adventure game. Talk to people, collect items, repeat. In this case, you collect stickers which you can apply to other characters and objects. However, the gameplay isn’t super deep. With one exception, each sticker is used exactly once and it’s not challenging at all. Just make an entire trip through the level talking to everyone on the way and they will literally tell you what sticker they need most of the time. 

There are also platforming sections but the only challenge is the fact that dudes chase you through the section if they see you. In the later levels, it gets pretty tedious because you basically have to stand in a particular location, place a sticker on a dude, and run for it. It’s trial and error rather than anything fun. 

[h1]Graphics/Performance: (with a 970, 4790K, 16GB of RAM, SSD)[/h1]
The art style of paper in a 3D environment is just fantastic and it really is super creative visually. Not a fan of the characters personally but I can see that a lot of love went into the visuals. The voice acting is varied and there are a lot of characters but see above for boring characters. Ran great and never crashed.
 
[h1]Final Thoughts:[/h1]
It’s really not bad and normally I wouldn’t mind something like this but the story was just super uninteresting. When I’m skipping the dialog in an adventure game, it’s kinda failed me.

33289676.review:
A 2.5d puzzle platformer desperately trying to be Psychonauts, but without any interesting characters or gameplay.

Aside from the obviously Double Fine inspired art direction, this game reminds me of Double Fine’s The Cave in how simplistic it’s puzzles are. Levels are long, self-contained 2.5 platforming sets, like The Cave. Single level puzzles ensure that everything will be wrapped up neatly and that there will never be a challenge. There aren’t even red herring puzzle items, like The Cave. Puzzles are extremely obvious due to the mind reading effect, which tells you the answer.
For example: A dog says, “I wish I had teeth so I could bite these dudes” and by sheer coincidence you have a crocodile tooth sticker. 
There are only two scenarios in which you'll have a spare item and both of those are used for achievement related side-puzzles. The result is a puzzle game with no challenging puzzles. 

The jokes are really hit or miss and a lot of them are references. Yes, you did a Mario joke, well done; that horse was beaten into a red paste 20 years ago, what else do you got? Aside from “humorous” observations, the game's other running joke is giving animals antiquated Shakespearean accents and vocabularies that can only be discovered by reading their minds. It's funny the first time, but when every single animal talks like a Victorian-era art critic, it loses its charm faster than a Leprechaun on speed. 

Probably the biggest difference between The Cave and Stick it to the Man is the atmosphere. The Cave took place in dark empty areas with one or two NPCs. Stick it to the Man occurs in large city environments and is based on quietly helping other characters solve their problems. I was actually really impressed by one aspect: Most puzzles have a running theme of repairing unlikely relationships. Unfortunately, that's the game's only real source of inspiration and, paired with the frankly huge cast of one-dimensional characters, the atmosphere loses its charm faster than a Leprechaun on speed. 

The voice acting is just terrible. Let me explain. In voice work, characters have funny voices; funny voices don’t make characters. With little exception, every character has a similarly overextended speech pattern and a wacky accent which proves to be more distracting than funny or immersive. 
The main character's voice sounds like a cheese grater with a New York accent. 
In fairness though, some of the worst voice work comes from horrific dialogue writing. 
You’ll hear “I should have not stayed up all night LAST NIGHT eating burritos, yet I have no regret about eating burritos all night,” and similar lines about micro-naps dozens and dozens of times. This attempt at humor (its not really a joke) would only have been funny once, but the game design forces you to commit the greatest sin in all of comedy games: repeating the joke over and over and over and over again. It loses its charm faster than a Leprechaun on speed. 

Dr. Brom (who is based on Dr. Monroe from The Simpsons), the taxidermist, blue haired radio operator, and the mother are the only consistently good character voices in the entire game. 
Ray (the PC) and Ted (the alien that lives inside his head) are the worst voices, by far.

Yet even the voice acting cannot compare to the hideous "plot" of this game. From the get go, the plot is essentially the PC being chased by bad guys. There's an apparent mystery with a psychologist (who Ray has never met before) but it doesn't go anywhere. Despite having a huge set up, nothing in this game's storyline has any pay off.  The antagonist makes a number of intro-cutscene apperances, but they don't amount to anything. You make it to the end of your 3 hour journey and nothing is gained. You don't know why the bad guy is evil and neither does he. Once he finally gets what he wants he say something to the effect of "Why did I do this anyway?" The antagonist is as confused as the player. The result is a comedy puzzle game that fails to be funny and has no interesting puzzles, but does have a host of one-dimensional characters, terrible voice acting, and a nonsense plot (even for a game that takes place in a world of stickers and cardboard). 

$15 for 3 hours of terrible puzzles, terrible writing, terrible voice acting, and a terrible story.

31945172.review:
TL;DR DON'T WATCH THE TRAILER.  It's short. It's linear. It's funny, but maybe not hilarious. It's good. I don't want to stiff the developers, but I would wait for a sale. 

This is a fun game, I never got the feeling while I was playing that it was intended to be hard, and that definitely works in it's favor. Reminds me of monkey island, but mostly in tone. There aren't really 'puzzles' per se, but you progress by reading everyone's mind, and finding which stickers go to their relative place in the world. 

This is actually my biggest gripe with the game. Maybe it's just me, but I thought it would play like I was running around with a bunch of stickers, randomly putting it on the world and seeing the chaos, eventually finding the one I needed to progress through the story. 

That's not what this is.

All stickers except one that I remember(and it's at the end), have one place they go. That's it. And I don't mean to say that some of the pairings aren't *really funny or chaotic, but I was looking forward to a more open-ended experience. I would play the heck out of a game like that. 

 And if, for some reason, you're reading this before seeing the trailer, DON'T WATCH IT. 
There are a huge amount of sticker pairings that I knew just from watching it. Seriously; It kind of felt like a lot of the game was given away from that. 

In the end, if you think you'll like it, you probably will. 
I was not disappointed.

30605225.review:
Personal Rating: 6.5 of 10

This is indeed a bizzare platformer. It is basically a 2.5D puzzle platformer that requires you to solve a series of quest by reading and fulfilling what is on people's mind by grabbing and placing stickers. This is fairly easy as they were logical and it was meant to be relaxing and funny I guess.

Sometimes, in order to get to the other area, you need proper planning, timing, good reflex and precision. Sounds complicated? Well, it the entire map is sometimes separated by a small maze platforms with enemies which you need to avoid. You can read their mind to get stickers use these stickers to plan your moves. These parts can be frustrating because you cannot see beyond the area and usually you need grab a tack, which can appear anywhere, to pass the area while getting chased. If you missed the tack or fail to find it like within a second you need to restart the area. Anything frustrating thing when you try to stick a sleeping sticker to the enemy and he just happened to be standing in front of a tack you will grab the tack and fly towards the enemy instead. This happens 100% of the time. However, these areas are usually small and restarting is fairly quick. Character movement may take a little adjustment to get used to but menial matter.

The art style is very good and keeps thing interesting. Game design is great as everything is presented to you straight to the point. Controls is solid and so is the voice acting. Music is catchy and gels with the game nicely.

29018496.review:
For the record, I have no clue why this game is called "Stick it to The Man" even if you don't end up sticking anything to him throughout the entire game and the titular "man" doesn't become a promint figure until the final chapter. But I think "Weird Wavy Purple Hand Sticking out of Head and sticking various stickers onto other objects and backgrounds" would have been too long of a title.

Anyway, this is my first time really reviewing a game (I'm mostly a film reviewer, so I'm sorry if I seem a bit out of touch and this review itself being all over the place) and I figured it would be of one I got during the big sale recently and thought was worth talking about. 

I never heard of this game until the sale and even then, I did it mostly because it was cheap and thought it looked cute enough. "Stick it to The Man" tells the story of Ray, a guy who lives in a world made up entirely out of paper materiel and stickers. After getting hit on the head, he suddenly wakes up with a big purple hand sticking out of his head and now has the ability to read minds and pull down various objects in the backgrounds and foregrounds. 

It's pretty straight forward in terms of gameplay: grab objects, stick them to others, run, jump, read minds of anyone to figure out what thing to stick on them, etc and etc. 

Oh, and you also must avoid being caught by henchmen of "The Man" in these small segments that appear every now and then in chapters, along with using your purple hand to grab onto thumbtacks as a grappling hook. 

It's decently done and kept me playing, but it's nothing I doubt many familiar with adventure games or platformers will think is breaking any new grounds. Puzzles are fairly easy to figure out (but still rather fun to do so) and for the most part, the levels go by in a snap if you know what you need to do with certain stickers and characters.

In the grand scheme of things, Gameplay doesn't really seem to main focus of the team behind this. The main focus seems to be mostly on the various types of quirky characters and very odd scenarios/solutions for puzzles and see how many laughs they can get out of the player. 

I can't really say this game is flat out hilarious or even THAT much nuanced to the weird comedy genre, but there's something oddly charming about it.

The art direction looks like "The Simpsons" meets "Psychonauts" with this odd cardboard and paper aesthetic that's equal parts fun to look at and very bizarre, along with the soundtrack, which is pretty fun too (give "Get me a Shrink!" a listen to if you're in the mood for some funky jazz)

The writing in general kept me consistently chuckling and laughing through, but I dunno, it all feels.......token? Like, I've felt like I've seen these types of punchlines before but I can't put my finger on where exactly (it could be Matt Groening, Tim Schafer, or Dan Povenmire, but it could be something else entirely), but they're still funny and it made me want to see where it would go next. 

Voice acting is pretty solid across the broad, but there's some moments (mostly during jokes) that the timing of the punchlines feel a bit off, which for a comedy game is a pretty big fail, but it doesn't happen as often as I was dreading. 

The weird characters you meet throughout the journey are pretty interesting to watch in the "what the hell is going to be the outcome for him/her?" sorta way and the game itself ends on a fairly nice punchline. 

If there's any other issue in regards to gameplay, I would say the segments with the henchmen get pretty tedious after awhile and it's often annoying to be reading the mind of one, only to then have them walk out of the frame you can do so as they charge over to you, with a small delay between moments of getting in control again.

I would say as well it's A BIT over priced (?) for four hours of standard Adventure Game stuff if that's what you're looking for, but if you're looking for a breezy, simple, and charming little time killer, stick this one into your chart.

7/10

28727765.review:
Stick It To The Man is a hilarious adventure game first, but it also contains elements of platforming and stealth, and it's what I imagine what would look like if Beetlejuice-era Tim Burton made a stage play.  You play as Ray, a regular man with a regular life who by accident is suddenly merged with an alien entity named Ted, who confers him telepathy and telekinesis via a giant purple hand that sticks out of his head.  On the run from a shady organization with evil plans, Ray must find a way to return to normal while also stopping the organization, all the while using his newfound powers to help people around him.

I've been interested in this game since its release, but I've put off its purchase for a long time.  I instantly regretted that once I started playing.  This game is easily worth its full price.  Following the storyline and getting every achievement will net you between 4 to 5 hours of playtime, which is the perfect spot for the price while still mantaining the novelty of the gameplay.

It's a really easy game (though, like in all adventure games, you're bound to get stuck for a bit at least once), it's more about the experience than the challenge.  Outlandish characters, fourth-wall breaking, and overall funny dialogue are the meat of the game.  Gameplay-wise, the majority consists of using your abilities to solve puzzles, by both reading minds and make use of stickers to change around the environment.  There's also some light platforming and a few stealth sections, but they're there just to add some variety and they're mostly a means to an end.  They're not by any means bad, they're just the least interesting part of the experience.

What else can I say?  Buy this game now, you won't regret it.

28247164.review:
Pro tip: Try TURNING OFF SUBTITLES to make the game funnier! I don't know if it is just me, but I really wish someone had told me this before I got so far into the game. 

This game is not very long (took 6 hours of playtime to complete), very challenging, or (I suspect) very replayable. Play it for the amazing visual style and the humor. The writing is not as consistently excellent as the visual presentation. But, at least in my experience, the writing feels a lot less stiff and more amusingly quirky without subtitles. 

I started out with subtitles on and was having a hard time getting into the game. Then I turned them off by accident and suddenly found myself enjoying the game significantly more. 

One thing I wish the game had was more flexibility in applying stickers. As far as I can tell, each sticker has one right usage, and when you try the wrong sticker, nothing happens. It would be much more interesting if there were multiple viable ways to use stickers, or if they at least had some amusing things happen when using the wrong sticker.

Stick it to The Man! é um jogo adventure clássico: percorra os mapas, converse com pessoas, troque informações e resolva tudo o que todos querem. O jogo foi concebido para ser bem divertido e tem a duração padrão de um indie, 4 horas de jogatina. Neste tempo você vai escutar diversas piadas e vivenciar as mais inusitadas situações.

A arte do jogo casa com a jogabilidade voltada para plataformas, onde a movimentação é feita num ambiente 2.5D cujos cenários e personagens têm aparência de papel. Enquanto o jogo brinca com o aspecto de cartolina e papelão dos ambientes, como o antigo Paper Mario, o jogador ganha o poder telecinético e de leitura de mentes, como o antigo Psychonauts. Através dessa leitura de mentes, você descobre as fraquezas e necessidades de cada personagem e o que cada um deseja.

Stick it to The Man! é um jogo com personalidade, que junta diversos elementos para criar uma aventura bem humorada e divertida. Por horas um pouco frustrante, devido algumas decisões de design ou até mesmo por personagens chatos que falam demais, o jogo não se deixa abalar e entretem por toda a sua duração.

Recomendo o jogo em uma promoção para uma sessão descontraída de diversão

The mind reading, platforming, adventure, stealth and paper tearing mechanics take chances and fit great together. Add funny writing, great voice acting, memorable characters, a great style and a superb soundtrack and its a wholly fun time. A minus point is that some of the puzzles verge on moon logic and some items don't work when they feel they should. For instance, near the beginning of the game there are two puzzles that revolve around teeth going on at the same time, so which solution fit where was a bit confusing. These issues are common in many excellent adventure games though (Grim Fandango for example) and in this case don't distract from the many, many great things this game has to offer.  I'm the kind of person who exhausts every dialogue tree in an adventure game so I really enjoyed reading minds and learning about the misfits who inhabit this crazy paper world. Great stuff, I'm happy I grabbed it on Chrono.gg when it was on sale!

22172128.review:
A severely overlooked game - it seems like it has a really small amount of players across all of its platforms; and yet I imagine that there is a really large amount of people who would enjoy this game so much!

Now, the first thing that I will say is that the game is pretty short and can be completed (100%) in 5 hours, or probably under that. However, I did not regret my purchase of this game at all. Worst case scenario for you: Just buy it on sale, and you should have no issues.

This game is so unique and drew me in much more than I expected. The story, from a high-level perspective, is a bit cheesy, and the villain of the game is also somewhat annoying and lacks thrill, BUT that is intentional to fit with the overall style of the game. It is really off-the-wall, filled with random silly jokes and a good bit of dark humor (a couple of places are surprisingly dark), but it all flowed together, in an intentionally messy way.

The art is in this paper and sticker format, which actually was done in such a way that I enjoyed it very much. It was not tacky at all. Everything is very well drawn, and a good amount of the level design and characters have this interesting sort of dreary, grimy look. Some items, buildings, people, and so on, are brighter and stand out from everything else that has a background tone or shading, but the background itself is really detailed and by all means should be looked at just as much as the stuff with which you interact.

The theme song of the game was a very good pick, and the sounds and music as you play are pretty simple in most places, but also enjoyable. I did not have a problem with anything that I heard in the game. Then you have the voice acting, which was amazing. So many characters voiced by a small amount of people, and they were definitely unique as well. I didn't notice any characters sounding too close to each other.

The game itself is split into chapters, or essentially levels, and you must explore the levels and solve small puzzles where other characters are wanting specific objects. You must find the objects either lying around somewhere, or by obtaining them from other characters. As you help certain characters out, they will sometimes do things like break/open doors for you to continue on in the level, or end up giving you another item that you will have to figure out how to use. While the general idea is simple or not necessarily exciting, the game really benefits from its style as mentioned above, as well as the actual gameplay of how you will do the puzzle-solving.

Your character, Ray, has an accident and ends up with a weird arm sticking out of his head, which in and of itself allows for the gameplay. The game is an interesting mix of platforming and point-and-click, where you use your mouse to control the arm and grab objects that you need, as well as do something stranger: read other characters' minds. When you read their minds, you will sometimes just hear thoughts and jokes, while other times will give you hints about what to currently do in a level (e.g., what a character might be looking for), or even end up having a character release a thought cloud which contains an item that you can grab and carry with you.

Don't worry, though: You shouldn't get bored by the above, as the level design and characters are very interesting (as I know I have said multiple times so far), and just about every time you give an item to someone, a cutscene will occur showing some wacky events happening that will very likely make you laugh (assuming you enjoy the humor of the game). Hence, I had fun every single minute of the game, running around and figuring out what to do with so many weird items and people you encounter.

Again, I will say that the game surprised me. I watched some of the trailers and thought it seemed really odd, and maybe funny, but I didn't go in with any fancy expectations. It turned out to be a lot more than what I felt while watching the trailers. So, unless you absolutely hate the scenes in the trailers, I would say to give the game a chance, even if you are on the fence or somewhat unsure. I expect that you will also be surprised like I was. I really recommend this game.

20706007.review:
[b]"Stick It To The Man"[/b] is a really interesting adventure platformer. Developed by indie studio [b]Zoink Games[/b] and published by [b]Ripstone[/b], this game was quite a surprise for me. It tells the story of a mediocre guy named Ray, who gains the ability to read people's minds. He gets into a pretty 'sticky' ([i]god, forgive me[/i]) situation, as the reason for his telepathic abilities is something which is highly sought after. The game introduces the antagonist and his minions, who you have to avoid at all cost, seeing as you are still in the body of an average dude. As you can probably guess - the aforementioned abilities are the key to this. The story is written in a very funny way and I found the dialogues to be insanely enjoyable. I can say that the story made me laugh several times.
The gameplay is pretty interesting, as you have to gather items to proceed. This makes you explore the world, which is adorable and full with stories. The only quirk that the game has are the little points in levels, where you meet the baddies. You have some cool techniques to avoid them, but sometimes those scenes are a bit frustrating to manoeuvre through. Since they are not that many and the game unlocks a kind of "fast travel system", it is easy to forgive that. The puzzles are really innovative and fun.
The art-style is somehow gorgeous. Yes, the figures are really ugly, but this kind of grotesque depiction really makes them amicable. The world has a Little-Big-Planet-kind-of-look, since everything seems to be made out of cardboard. The music is perfect, the cool jazz tunes don't make you hurry up your gameplay. The only thing is that sometimes the dialouge gets a bit messed up, but it hasn't been anything all too tragic. You can turn on subtitles anyway.
As a whole, I have to say that this game was a nice experience. It is very comparable to [i]Psychonauts[/i], but with a heavier focus on the adventure, than on the platforming. A definite recommendation on my part!

You can use your mental powers to find stickers all over the world that you can use to accomplish different tasks. For example, you can read someone's thoughts so they start thinking about something, which appears as a sticker in a thought balloon, which you can now place on them to put them to sleep! It's kind of like a 2.5-D puzzle-platformer (more like 2.75-D, since you can occasionally move in the third dimension), but with true 3D depth in the scenery. Attention to detail is amazing. This game is great. The art style and soundtrack are immediately appealing. The story is humorous, weird, and actually pretty dark at times; but it tells it's story without ever taking itself too seriously.

18583251.review:
Ray es un tio normal con una vida y un trabajo gris y aburrido hasta que un buen dia sufre un accidente y un contenedor caido desde un avión de transporte le cae en la cabeza. El contenedor transporta a Ted, una criatura alienigena cautiva por una malvada organización, Ted toma refugio en el interior de la mente de Ray el cual se despierta sin saber que ha pasado ni por que tiene una mano-espagueti-rosa-fantasma-gigante que sale de la parte superior de su cabeza, que solo el puede ver y que le da el poder de leer las mentes de otros. A partir de ese momento la vida de Ray cambia y se convierte en el objetivo de la malvada organización controlada por el oscuro y siniestro villano conocido solo como "The man".

Pequeña gran joya a medio camino entre la aventura grafica y las plataformas que se desarrolla en un mundo hecho completamente por papel y cartón, donde manejamos a Ray y su mano espagueti con la que podemos leer las mentes de la gente e incluso atrapar sus pensamientos en forma de pegatinas que pueden ser colocadas en otros sitios para resolver los diferentes niveles, tambien puede ser usada como si del látigo de Indiana Jones se tratara para ir colgandonos por las chinchetas que hay repartidas por ahí, y que nos serviran para burlar a los secuaces de "the man" que no dudarán en darnos caza si nos ven. Tan fácil como apuntar y lanzar.

Graficamente es un juego muy vistoso y colorido, y tanto entornos como personajes están magnificamente ilustrados. La jugabilidad es ágil y sencilla, podremos movernos libremente por escenarios recogiengo y usando pegatinas, que nos darán nuevos objetos o abrirán zonas nuevas del mapa. por otro lado la dificultad no es muy elevada y la información que se obtiene al leer las mentes no suele dejar mucho lugar a dudas de donde usar cada objeto. No es muy largo, pero la duración está bastante bien para ser una aventura gráfica (unas 7 horas incluyendo repetir algunos niveles para conseguir los logros). Por ultimo la banda sonora está muy bien y pega perfectamente, ademas cuenta como tema principal con la conocida "Just Dropped In" de Kenny Rogers & The First Edition.

Gráficos bonicos, dialogos divertidos y diversión asegurada. dialogos y subtitulos en inglés.

8/10

18131862.review:
[h1]Описание:[/h1]
 Веселый квест с элементами платформера. Мы играем за веселого парня Рэя живущего в странном бумажном мире, где большинство объектов бумажные стикеры наклеенные на основной фон. Наш герой Рэй обычный парень, у него есть девушка, работа и ничто не предвещало бы беды, если бы работа Рэя не заключалась в тестировании строительных касок на самом себе. В процессе очередного теста в нашего главного героя вселяется инопланетный организм и Рэй получает благодаря своему новому другу уникальную возможность читать чужие мысли. И все бы хорошо, мы теперь можем помогать людям и изменить нашу жизнь к лучшему, но нет... Об инопланетном госте узнает злодей под именем - Мужик, которых хочет заполучить пришельца в свои руки. И это еще не все, попутно наш главный герой немножко копается разными путями в своих мыслей в результате чего мы иногда будем путешествовать и по мозгу главного героя. В техническом плане суть игры сводится к тому, чтобы на уровне собирать различные стикеры и использовать их в нужных местах, чтобы постепенно добраться до конца уровня, попутно избегая врагов. Вся игра приправлена толстым слоем качественного юмора и сделана довольно на высоком уровне.

[h1]Плюсы:[/h1]
¥ Музыка/озвучка выполнено на высоком уровне и приятны для ушек.
¥ Качественный юмор.
¥ Красивая прорисовка мира, персонажей в стилистике бумажных стикеров.
¥ Необычное сочетание двух жанров - платформер и квест
¥ В руководствах к игре есть русификатор (субтитры).

[h1]Минусы:[/h1]
¥ Игра чрезмерно проста, за все прохождение не разу не возникло какой-то трудной загадки или участка с врагами где я не смог бы пройти.

[h1]Достижения:[/h1]
Достижения для выполнения достаточно просты и их можно получить при одном полном прохождении, затем подгружая уровни в которых нужно пройти что-то отдельно.

[h1]Итог:[/h1]
Веселая игра которую прошел с большим удовольствием. Порадовала смесь платформера с квестом и после прохождения остались исключительно положительные эмоции с радостью увидел бы продолжение. Рекомендую.

[h1]Оценка: 
¥ Графика: 7/10
¥ Музыка/Звук: 8/10
¥ Сюжет: 7/10
¥ Управление: 8/10
¥ Геймплей: 8/10
Итог: 8/10[/h1]

[h1]Послесловие:[/h1]
Если вам понравился этот обзор добро пожаловать в группу
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/uojer - тут вы сможете увидеть рекомендованные мною игры, другие обзоры, а также просто пообщаться в хорошей компании.

En son ne zaman bir platform oyununu bitirdiğimi sorsanız cevap için epey düşünmek zorunda kalırdım. Geçen sene "Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons"u bitirmiştim. Oynanış süresi kısa bir oyundu lakin oynanış dinamikleri ve hikayesiyle beni gerçekten etkilemişti. Birkaç gün önce de Outland'i deneyimleme fırsatım olmuştu. Yaklaşık bir saatimin oyun süremde memnun ayrılmadığımı söylesem yalan olur ama öncelikle incelemem gereken bir oyun vardı, dikkatimi başka oyunlara veremezdim. Evet, doğru tahmin ettiniz; Yeni nesil konsollar, PS3 ve PC'de çıkışını gerçekleştiren Stick It to The Man bugünkü incelememizin konuğu.

Bir Meslek Ne Kadar Tuhaf Olabilir?

Ana karakterimiz Ray, gayet eli yüzü düzgün, işine gücüne koşturan ve Arlene isminde bir eşi olan birisi. Ama gelin görün ki yaptığı iş biraz "fantastik" kaçıyor. İnşaatlarda kullanılan kaskları test etmesi gereken bir işi var Ray'in. Kafasına düşen tehlikeli parçalarla birlikte kaskların sağlamlığını kontrol ediyor ve eğer başına bir şey gelmezse bu kask geçerlidir onayını yapıştırıyor tabiri caizse. İş dönüşü yolda yürürken birden kafasına bir kargo uçağından ne idüğü belirsiz bir paket düşüveriyor ve o andan sonra maceramız başlıyor.

Ray'in kafasında artık fosforlu pembe renkte uzantılar var ve bu uzantılar sayesinde insanların (ve bazen hayvanların) düşüncelerini okuyabiliyor. Tabi ki bu kadar değerli bir paketin öylesine sıradan bir insana yâr olmasını istemeyen kötü niyetli birisi de adamlarını Ray'in üzerine salıyor ve maceramız boyunca bu elemanlarla da uğraşmak zorunda kalıyoruz.

17282685.review:
¿Una aventura gráfica? ¿Un juego de plataformas? Ninguno de los dos, "Stick It To The Man!" es un juego que se queda a medio camino entre ambos géneros, y que gustará a los seguidores de ambos por igual.

En él manejamos a Ray, un pobre currante que ha hecho de probar cascos de seguridad su profesión, y que sufre un irónico accidente mientras vuelve a su casa tras el trabajo: Un misterioso (y contundente) objeto cae del cielo y le deja inconsciente.
Cuando despierta, Ray descubre que algo ha cambiado. De repente es capaz de escuchar los pensamientos ajenos. Pero no solo eso, si no que también será capaz de modificarlos (mediante la ingeniosa jugabilidad), e incluso de utilizar los pensamientos de otros para "materializar" objetos a su antojo.
A partir de aquí, la historia se basará en averiguar qué le ha pasado exactamente a nuestra cabeza, y por qué somos repentinamente buscados por unos agentes trajeados.
Todo está narrado en tono de humor, con geniales diálogos y multitud de momentos muy graciosos, que nos harán esbozar más de una sonrisa mientras nos preguntamos cómo terminará la historia.

El aspecto gráfico del juego es otra seña de identidad del mismo. Todo el mundo de "Stick It To The Man!" está creado mediante cartones y pegatinas. El resultado es una delicia, con escenarios tridimensionales por los que nos moveremos con un scroll lateral, y personajes y elementos en 2D situados en ellos.
El diseño es original, divertido, y muy muy trabajado (no hay dos lugares ni dos personajes iguales, si exceptuamos a los enemigos), y se nota en ciertos puntos una influencia de Psychonauts (además de haber alguna que otra referencia al juego). Termina siendo uno de esos juegos en que el simple hecho de querer ver más escenarios ya justifica el seguir avanzado.

La jugabilidad va de la mano con el diseño de los escenarios. Los poderes mentales de Ray están representados por una mano rosada (con aspecto de chicle) que le sale de la cabeza (y que nadie más puede ver). Con esta mano, que podremos controlar, seremos capaces de leer la mente de otros personajes, de recoger objetos del escenario (que reconoceremos por su forma de pegatina), e incluso de agarrar por ejemplo la fachada de papel de un edificio y desprenderla para ver qué hay en su interior.
Los objetos que encontremos pasarán a formar parte de nuestro inventario, y deberemos usarlos dónde corresponda para ir solucionando puzzles y poder continuar. Además de los que encontremos por el escenario, podremos incluso leer la mente a otros personajes que estén pensando en un objeto y "coger" ese objeto de su mente para usarlo a nuestro antojo, lo cual aumenta mucho las posibilidades.
A este aspecto de aventura gráfica (muy sencilla) hay que añadirle las partes de plataformeo y huida de enemigos. En el juego seremos perseguidos por una serie de enemigos en varios momentos, a los que no podremos derrotar. Sin embargo podremos darles esquinazo (temporalmente) de varias formas. Por ejemplo, podemos leer la mente de un enemigo que está pensando en dormir y "tomar" esa idea de su mente para ponérsela a otro, que caerá dormido. O podemos "tomar" la imagen de nuestra cara de un enemigo que nos esté buscando para poner esa imagen en la cara de otro enemigo, de modo que los demás le persigan creyendo que se trata de nosotros.
Ambas partes, tanto la de puzzles como la de plataformeo, son más bien sencillas durante la mayor parte del juego, pero funcionan lo suficientemente bien juntas para que la experiencia sea muy satisfactoria.

A todo esto hay que añadirle un buen doblaje (en inglés con subtítulos en castellano) y una banda sonora que cumple con creces.

Al final, "Stick It To The Man!" termina siendo una experiencia satisfactoria en todos sus aspectos, graciosa, divertida, y con un aspecto visual tremendamente bueno. ¡Habría que golpearse la cabeza muy fuerte para no verlo!

Here's the simplest way to put it: This game is fun.

It's an easy puzzler, and it's rather short. You get into an environment and you connect a few dots. None of it is too complicated. You don't have a billion items in your inventory to try on a billion different other things in the environment.

But here's the trick to that. That's ok. The environment is full of little yuks and fun things along the way. You know, content. You're doing the puzzles to keep getting through good content. You're not juggling a dozen puzzles and hints at a time. So as a puzzler alone, maybe it's less than one might expect. But as a game, it's excellently done.

With a little bit platformer, a little bit puzzle, and a little bit adventure, this game will keep you moving through fun environments with appropriate, enjoyable music.

16913245.review:
This is an odd one but odd in all the right ways. 

I am not a big fan of puzzle games, with a few exceptions like Machinarium, Samorost and, you've guessed it, Stick it to the man. In case of the one here we have a Puzzle - Platformer like game, with some adventure elements. If that does sound awfully broing to you hang on! It's not (ya I was kinda surpised myself). While the main thing you do in the game is running and jumping around there are a few unique and very interesting elements. I do not want to spoil the games story here so I'll just say this: You solve each level by reading the minds of people and tearing parts of the world apart. 

The story itself may not be deep but in conjunction with the graphical appearance of the game it is hilarious (and really, really weird at times). You'll probably never loose your smile playing the game, wich will probably entertain you for 5 to 6 hours if you do not use any guides (wich you shouldn't). Furthermore you'll have a lot of stuff to find, explore and see on your journey, if you pay somewhat close attention to the Dialogues (or monologues....), easter eggs and style. The (amazing) graphical style does go hand in hand with the games mechanics as well. The voice acting is flawless and all together I can't see anything else but a game that shows you all the love going into it. 

Now it certainly is stuffed with weird humor you need to get used to but it is worth it.

16179065.review:
This is a pretty fun game.  It's a 2-D puzzle platformer, which I'm usually not too fond of, but in this case, I didn't mind it.  The main draw of this game is its sense of humor.  The $15 price tag is a bit high, but then again I say that about 90% of the games I play.

The game plays fairly nice.  There's a bit of platforming, but it really isn't that challenging.  Some of the sections with enemies can be a bit tricky, but after a few attempts you can develop a strategy to get around them.  There are also puzzles which revolve around reading people's minds and moving stickers to manipulate the world around you.  The puzzles are really easy, as long as you're careful when exploring the levels.

The story's pretty good.  You're a guy named Ray, who got hit on the head after returning from work.  When you wake up, you realize that you have a hand sticking out of your head.  This hand can be used to grab stickers, pins, and read other people's minds, all of which are used to solve puzzles.  The story is unique, the dialogue is quite funny, and the voice acting is pretty nice.

If I had to make one complaint, it’s that the game is rather short.  It only lasted about 5 hours for me, and I even got all of the achievements.  What the game has is fine, but a little more wouldn’t hurt.

Overall, I would suggest picking this game up.  It will make you laugh, plus the achievements aren't too bad to 100%.  I just wish it was a little bit longer.

15475799.review:
Рэй - простой рабочий, который днём испытывает каски, а после работы возвращается к любимой Арлин, не имеет никаких проблем и совершенно доволен жизнью. И тут по дороге домой ему падает на голову загадочный контейнер, после чего Рэй внезапно получает невидимую руку из головы и способность читать мысли. Ах, да, и ещё теперь за ним охотится секретная служба.

Stick it to The Man - это комедия. Абсурдистская и местами чёрная, но добрая и симпатичная. И ещё всё сделано из бумаги - и это обыгрывается авторами неоднократно. Действующие лица, впрочем, воспринимают всё как должное, так что через полчаса игры и ты привыкаешь, что "второе я" успешного психиатра - это, буквально, его обратная сторона, а главный герой воскрешается на плоттере. Единственное, что меня смущает в этом подходе - это вольное обращение с частями тела, которые главный герой то и дело переклеивает с одного человека на другого... ну да пусть их. Сюжетная часть мне понравилась, так что вольности вполне оправданы.

Всю игру меня не покидало ощущение, что авторы вдохновлялись Психонавтами - хоть, казалось бы, общего у двух игр практически ничего. Тут скандинавы, там американцы, тут двумерная взрослая адвентюра, там трёхмерный всевозрастной платформер, тут заговоры и нежелательная беременность, там детский лагерь и охота за призами... а вот же.

Нет, ну если припрут к стене, я скажу, что герой мне очень напоминает Молочника, а антигерой мог бы быть родным братом Саши Найна, плюс проникновение в мозги, а каждый второй этап проходит в голове героя - но этого же мало! Но ничего не могу с собой поделать. Маскот Double Fine, который встречается ближе к середине игры, только укрепляет впечатление.

В игровом же плане игра... скажем так, довольно казуальна. Это Action-Adventure, сделанная по канонам, например, Dizzy 2. Те же активные места для предметов (которые невозможно выложить больше нигде), простенькие загадки, плоский мир и прыжки по платформам с умеренным экшеном. Сюжет разбит на "главы", и продвигается автоматически, как только вы выполните все задачи главы. Точки сохранения расставлены каждые 10 метров, при этом прогресс не теряется вообще - фактически, при смерти персонаж просто телепортируется к последнему плоттеру. Автокарта имеется, красиво оформлена в тон каждой главы, и там отмечены все точки интереса - причём использованные отличаются от активных.

Графика игры очень хороша, но ей мешает уродский движок. Он не держит больших разрешений, заставляя играть в окне, он скроллирует туда, куда хочется ему, и несмотря на физическую возможность, только волей геймдизайнера приближает или удаляет картинку. Почему этих функций не дали игроку - загадка. Это жутко порой бесит, потому что игра запросто скроет от тебя ступени внизу или противников вверху (равно как их отсутствие), раз движку захотелось дать крупный план. Основой геймплея является чтение мыслей - и тем не менее, процентов пять персонажей "прочесть" нельзя, потому что они слишком быстро уходят из поля зрения или в него просто не попадают в режиме чтения мыслей.

Ещё по какой-то загадочной причине авторы забыли упомянуть об инвентаре. Он вызывается колёсиком мыши, но обнаружил я это только в середине четвёртой главы.

Каждый уровень довольно маленький, и первоначально это меня напрягало. Но потом я познакомился поближе с движком, и понял, что дизайнеры сделали всё правильно: если бы карты были побольше, я бы выкинул игру на второй главе, не выдержав неравной борьбы.

В целом игру очень рекомендую - команда явно талантлива как в сюжетной, так и в графической части. Ещё бы программистов им поменять, да уйти от казуального геймплея - делали бы классику.

15338455.review:
[b]Note: video review embedded below.[/b]

Stick It To The Man’s unabashed insanity is its saving grace.

Though it took trudging through a serviceable yet tedious adventure game adjoined to an awkward platformer, developer Zoink’s oddball game about a dude who suddenly finds he can read people’s minds is so consistently amusing and clever that I found I rarely cared that I was only playing for the writing.

In a lot of ways Stick It To The Man is really refreshing. Few games venture into the realm of comedy, but Zoink jumps in head first with no reservations. Every line and character is progressively more absurd than the last, with each joke zipping by so fast you might miss it if you aren’t paying attention but making it easy to enjoy the ride due to having little time to actually dissect what’s going on.

stick it to the man pic 1If you were to break it down I doubt Stick It To The Man would elicit much more than a chuckle, but it’s how fully embedded it is in its ridiculous plot and satirical commentary that makes it all work. Every time I started the game it would take a moment to adjust to its outrageous style of humor, but a few minutes later I’d be sticking stickers all over things they don’t belong on and having an immensely good time watching the chaos unfold. Stick It To The Man is like a roller coaster that only goes up, with the stakes and quality of gags getting more and more insane the longer the game goes on even as you’re waiting for it to all come falling apart.

That’s not to imply Stick It To The Man is a particularly long game, clocking in around 3-4 hours, but it’s so densely packed that I think that’s all I could realistically take. It often felt like I’d been playing longer than I actually had simply do to how much stuff was always happening and continuing to happen even while I was trying to comprehend the scene before. It’s frankly a little exhausting to play, but in a way that makes you glad for its brevity because it ends right when you want it to.

There’s undeniably a lot of Stick It To The Man that’s little more than functional boredom, whether it’s the dull and obtuse puzzle designs or the few aggravating times you come across an enemy and have to manage the clumsy platforming controls to avoid them. There are only a few instances of this sprinkled throughout the game yet each always longer and worse than the last time you came across one. These scenes might work on a technical level, but there’s never any need for them to have been included.

But then everything circles around again to how delightfully written Stick It To The Man is even at its worst moments, and how that was more than enough to counteract its mechanical deficiencies for me. It’s as stupid as it is clever and delivered with enough style to make even the most cringeworthy joke work. Even though I can’t say I had a lot of fun playing Stick It To The Man, I was more than happy to spend some time reading the minds of its terrible, oh so entertaining hooligans.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7NzuvA9nImg
[b]You can read more of my writing on [url=http://kritiqal.com/2015/04/13/stick-it-to-the-man-review/]Kritiqal[/url].[/b]

В одной нарисованной местности, населенной картонными человечками, жил да был простой паренек-работяга. Работал он испытателем касок, имел много друзей, прекрасную девушку - в общем, все у него было хорошо. Пока однажды на землю не упал причудливый инопланетянин - и прямо нашему пареньку на голову. Точнее, в голову. Прямо в мозг просочился. С каждым случается. С вами пока не случалось? Не расстраивайтесь, все впереди.

В общем, заполучив себе в башку пришельца, паренек обрел способности к телекинезу, чтению мыслей, а также доставанию из чужих мыслей того, о чем люди думают, и наоборот - всовыванию в чужие мысли всяких предметов. Это нормально.

Проблема в том, что за этим пришельцем охотилась секретная служба, возглавляемая Мужчиной. Его так зовут. Нормальное имя. Командует он целой ордой амбалов-близнецов - тупых, зато дешевых. Реально, они почти бесплатно работают. Слишком тупые, чтобы попросить прибавку.

Ну и в общем, нашему герою надо преодолеть множество препятствий, чтобы не попасть в лапы к прави... хотя это не правительство, а какая-то левая шарашка, но не будем вдаваться в подробности. Поскольку мир здесь нарисованный, а все его жители картонные, приключения происходят в строго двумерном пространстве. А большую часть задач нужно решать с помощью новообретенных способностей - телекинез, чтение мыслей и прочая парапсихология.

Нужен тебе, скажем, таксист - до психиатра доехать. А таксист как раз вешаться собрался. Не то чтобы мы посягали на свободу эвтаназии, но как-то не вовремя. Нам такси нужно. Читаем его мысли - узнаем, что таксиста бросила девушка ради какого-то старого пeрдуна. Идем выяснять. Видим девушку, танцующую с этим старым пукой. Читаем ее мысли. Узнаем, что у девушки фетиш на большие блестящие зубы - а у старого пуки они вставные и очень красивые. Мастер пикапа! Туда-сюда, разруливаем, решаем еще пару побочных квестов и в итоге телекинезом забираем у старого пуки челюсти. Девушка его сразу бросает. А мы эти челюсти таксисту вставляем - опять-таки телекинезом. Теперь девушка любит таксиста. Красивое решение проблемы.

В общем, игра похожа на бред пьяного укурка. Но это чертовски смешно. И задачки весьма презанятные. Плюс история, несмотря на дикую кислотность, довольно-таки интересная. Так что смотрите сами, но учтите, что если вы эту игру не купите, пришельцы наcрут вам в мозг.

Я предупредил.

8 из 10.

14800859.review:
Stick it to The Man.

Although the game is relatively short (for me it took less than five hours to complete), it has charm and is a fun little spectacle to wade through over a weekend.

The game is basically about a guy who aquires the abilities to read minds and such after getting hit on the head by an alien spaceship. Throughout the journey the player is treated to different set pieces and many colorful characters along the way. There's a lot of comedy in the game but like all comedy it may not appeal to certain demographics; I found a few chuckles in my playthrough but I could see some might not enjoy the jokes as much as me.

As far as gameplay goes the player basically has to grab stuff and stick it to other stuff in hopes of advancing the plot, and along the way one's treated to interesting thoughts they can read. It's mostly a simple platformer puzzler with relatively easy puzzles, so it's not the most challenging game in the world. Most of the entertainment comes from the jokes and character interactions.

I'd say it's worth the money if you catch it on sale or on the Humble Bundle like I did.

14798679.review:
There are things I like about this game, and there are things which frustrate me a lot in this game. I enjoyed my time, but I can only recommend the game if you like a style and bizzare sense of humor (it's a pretty short game, you need 4-5 hours to finish it on your first playthorugh).

I like a style and a humor, and first couple of levels are very-very fun. Cut-scenes are fun and the game doesn't show you the same cut-scene if you die. If you replay some level, press backspace for 5 seconds to skip.

Voice acting is very good, and most of the dialogs are funny. And you can hold 'd' to speed up the speech if you are bored.

However, there are a lot of things I didn't like: it can be a problem with my PC, but controls feel clunky to me. I spend a lot of time retrying jumps of moving platforms. And I am not a new person to the platformers genre. Controls aren't rebindable (at least from the menus). Sometimes you think you can make the jump, but the platform is a bit far away. This won't be a problem, but you have goons in this game.

First two or three encounters with goons are good. However, after some time goons are not fun anymore. I just hoped it's the last goon on this level. Good thing you are not forced to do the same section more than once, developers provides you short cuts after you beat the section.

And the last thing: I liked some quests, but a lot of them are illogical. I finished a lot of the puzzles with brute force, and  sometimes, couldn't get a logic even after finish.

14734328.review:
Stick it to The Man! tries to be an offbeat and funny sidescrolling platformer, and it mostly succeeds.

You start the game by getting hit on the head and developing a superpower which lets you read other people's minds and conjure/manipulate objects in the world (which are called stickers). With the help of these stickers you solve all the "puzzles" in the game. I put puzzles in quotations because they're not real puzzles, there is basically no thinking involved, you just try sticking every sticker where it is possible and you solve it, that's all there is to it.

Similarly, there is no difficulty involved with the platforming in the game. And sadly the same goes for avoiding the enemies. They move in predictable patterns and it's easy to lose them even if you get spotted, that means that you're just going thorugh the motions most of the time.

Despite all that the story, dialogue and art style are here to save the game. It's hard to do humour in video games and Stick it to The Man! manages just that quite often. I am not talking about laugh out loud moments, but I was most certainly entertained throughout the game, even if there is a bit too much of listening to oneliners when you're reading people's minds. Finally, the art style alone is worth checking out, it gives the illusion of everything being made from paper or carboard and it achieves a very nice effect which doesn't get old until  the end.

I couldn't recommend the game based on the gameplay alone, however the style of the game is absolutely worth checking out.

6½ / 10

14633139.review:
Stick it to The Man! é um jogo indie que logo de cara nos mostra sua proposta: irreverência e bom humor (que por algumas vezes chega a flertar o humor-negro).
O jovem Ray, um cara comum e meio idiota, está tranquilamente vivendo sua rotina, quando uma acidente acontece, e ele leva uma pancada na cabeça. Um grande braço rosa de espaguete sai de sua cabeça, e ele passa a ter a habilidade de ler a mente das outras pessoas (e é esse o principal foco do jogo). O braço também o permite interagir com o mundo à sua volta, (que aliás, é feito de recortes de papel, assim como todos os personagens), puxando partes do cenário ou colando adesivos em horas oportunas.
O jogo é basicamente um misto de plataforma e puzzle, divido em dez capítulos, nos quais o jogador poderá explorar horizontal ou verticalmente o mapa, lendo as mentes dos personagens na tentativa de resolver alguns problemas (como conseguir uma dentadura e aumentar a auto-estima de um homem que planeja cometer suicídio). Ler as mentes é, sem dúvida, a melhor parte do jogo. É impossível não rir em algum momento com os pensamentos idiotas de alguns dos personagens (que também são os mais bizarros possíveis).
Visualmente, o jogo é impecável, apresentando com um estilo que remete ao clássico Paper Mario. A trilha sonora também é digna de elogios, com músicas que empolgam  e conseguem criar o clima necessário em cada capítulo. A dublagem, por sua vez, é de altíssimo nível, ainda mais quando falamos de um jogo indie.
Como único ponto negativo, podemos citar a duração do jogo, que é relativamente curto, e o fator replay, que é inexistente (a menos que se busque alguma conquista deixada para trás).

Only a few chapters in, and I couldn’t resist writing something up---Stick it to The Man! oozes charisma. Be it the smooth jazz tracks playing in the background, or the delightfully strange and wonderful characters inhabiting an equally kooky cardboard-cut-out universe. 

Reading others’ minds is a voyeuristic pleasure, especially when the dialogue is brought to life by genuinely amusing and convincing voice acting. The artwork and art direction are on point, too. Designs and illustrations are reminiscent of 90’s cartoons, a la Rocko’s Modern Life and Ren & Stimpy. I particularly enjoy the portraits that adorn the map screen for any given area.

A lot of care has been taken to ensure the player is thrust into a lively, yet bizarre rendition of a down-town, American city. A game highly recommended for anyone wanting to jump into something fun, light-hearted, and completely silly, which also sports incredible polish.

[Edit: After completing the game]

What an incredible ride! If you’re not into platforming, or somehow the art-style doesn’t take your fancy, play this game anyway for the consistently hilarious skits.

Fun little game that reminds me of something Double Fine/Tim Schafer would make.  It's a platforming puzzler where you pick up stickers in the area or from reading the minds of the colorful cast and placing them to progress. This isn't a very difficult or long game, but the humorful dialogue is really where the game shines.

Pros
-humorous
-interesting art style
-plenty of game and movie references

Cons
-the jump controls can be wonky sometimes. It's sort of like the older Castlevanias where you're locked in to your jump distance. Largely, this isn't a problem outside of a few horizontal jumping segments.
-I had a few times where a sticker couldn't be pulled or placed. If you have it go off screen and come back, it tends to fix itself.

Notes
-Press M to bring up the map
-You can skip cutscenes by holding Backspace. This is useful if you're going back through the chapters to read the minds you've missed
-I've got 5.3 hours logged for total completion (with about half an hour or so of idle time). This can either be a pro or con, depending on your budget and free time. All in all, the game feels very complete and tells a whole narrative, while still having an opening for a sequel.

14009227.review:
Stick it to the Man! is an adventure game, using 2D puzzle-platforming as the vehicle for its clumsy humor. You'll solve puzzles by reading people's minds, and manipulating them into thinking about a certain item that you can use somewhere else on the chapter. It's certainly not a hard game, with it nicely structured levels, always subtly guiding your way, never proving frustrating.

It's been said to be "Psychonauts" spiritual successor. While I have not played Psychonauts, I've played other Double Fine games, and the influence is clear! While the game mechanics don't seem to take the spotlight, they're very well conceived, and fit very well with the game's theme and aesthetics. It was one of the more enjoyable games I've recently played!


[b][u]Presentation[/u][/b]
This is probably the highlight in this game. Everything from the visuals, to the music and the voice acting is awesome!
It's a very colorful game, done in 2.5D. This is achieved by making every sprite like a cardboard cutout. The levels are then set in layers. While the game is mostly 2D, you can sometimes walk back and forth, discovering some charming details that would otherwise be blurred.
The character design is also great. While everyone looks silly, their designs clearly shows their personality, coupled with the problems you'll solve and the voice acting... It's good.

The [b]music[/b] is mostly jazz (it reminded me of the bebop soundtrack in Grim Fandango, maybe a bit silly at times) with a bit of sci-fi synth thrown in, at times. I really liked it, and it's certainly something that not only fit the game, but it's also something I'll listen to after I'm finished with the it! (You can get it here: http://stickittotheman.bandcamp.com/releases with a PayWhatYouWant model)
The [b]sound-effects[/b] Also fit well with the cartoony style. Never felt out of place, so that's good.

The [b]voice-acting[/b] was also great! Reinforcing the characters and the overall feel of the game, and was mostly well done! There were a few characters that felt a bit inconsistent, but nothing too major. Also, you can rewind and fastforward their speech, making the voices even sillier, with a higher tone, if you're in a hurry. It's these details that make this game so enjoyable, honestly!

The game's [b]writing[/b] is great as well! It's not anything deep, as you can imagine (although it does hint at some major issues, in a very lighthearted way), but it's certainly funny, if you're into this kind of humor.


[b][u]General Structure[/u][/b]
The game's divided by chapters, each with its theme, set of characters and puzzles. You can always go back to previous chapters through the menu, so you don't need to worry about missing an objective and being blocked from going back. This is something I very much appreciate! I hate being blocked for apparently no reason. 
Most of the chapters also have some achievements. Most of them are just a guide to silly characters that were more well hidden. It's a good use of them, to be honest! There are a couple of them that were more skill-based, if you're into that. But the Stick it to the Man! is a very laid-back game, and it never really tests your skills or patience.
Each level has lots of checkpoints, and you'll never lose any progress. The worst that can happen is you being sent a few meters back, but you never lose items or conversations.

Each level is about 20-40 minutes long. It felt just the right length for me. I played each chapter in one sitting, sometimes 2, and it never felt too short or to drag on. Also, since the levels can be fairly long, walking back would be a pain. As such, they've implemented a sort of fast travel system. Once you reach a certain point, a pipe open up, and you can go back instantly (and go forward once again).

It's a very comfortable game to play, as weird as it sounds. It's never frustrating, you're unlikely to walk around back and forth pointlessly, it's not punishing... just a nice, funny experience, overall.

[b][u]Mechanics[/u][/b]
Basically, you're hit on the head, and an alien just happens to [i]casually[/i] get into your brain. When that happens, a giant floppy pink hand grows out of your head, which only you can see. Nah, of course you're not crazy! It's [i]alieeeens[/i]. 

Anyway. This giant hand gives you the ability of reading people's minds, and materialize their thoughts. As freeing as it sounds, it's a very "linear" game. They'll only think of things you need, of course.
When you encounter a character, you'll learn about their problems, and then have to find the solution, somewhere. The game's is very similar to a point n' click. However, while the solution aren't too obvious, at first (since they're very non-sensical -- in a good way!), you can easily find everything by walking around and getting more items. If you have more than one, you'll store them, and can switch between them with the mouse-wheel.
If you stay put, your character will also say something about the item, leading you in a general direction. There are also very subtle environmental hints, so I doubt you'll get stuck.

So yeah. You'll walk around the level, speaking to the characters and reading their thoughts, often leading to some very peculiar situations, as you solve their problem in funny ways.

Again, it's not a game you'd play for the mechanics, but they're still very well put together! They fit with the theme, and even amplify it, never proving a nuisance, unlike other games in a similar style. It's very well designed!


It's pretty hard for me to get more to talk about. The game is very good, but it doesn't seem to do anything that jumps out at you. Everything just seems to fit together brilliantly, to me.

[b][i]For an adventure game, the 2D platforming certainly helped, against the traditional Point n' Click style[/i][/b]
Usually, games like this opt for the point n' click genre, rather than 2D platforming. As a result, their movement system is also very clunky and slow, going around the screens, taking seconds of waiting at a time. Stick it to the Man! avoids that entirely, by giving you total control at all times!
It makes the game incredibly better, in my eyes. It's not that I have anything against Pn'C games, but I usually find myself frustrated when I have to walk back and forth very slowly, simply to try a random combination of items.
This game, however, makes movement faster, and every scene seems to have [i]some[/i] little detail that makes the walking around even more enjoyable.

[b][i]Lack of punishment[/i][/b]
There are games that benefit from being punishing and challenging. This is not one of them, and the developers recognized it very well. It's not that there isn't [i]any[/i] challenge. There certainly is (mostly by being chased around the guards -- which people didn't enjoy very much!), but even if you "fail", you don't lose progress, and the more challenging sections are short, just keeping things varied. 

[b][i]The puzzles keep moving you forward[/i][/b]
Last point I want to make. You rarely have to backtrack to solve a puzzle, at least to the point of annoyance. You'll usually gather items as you go, and use them either very near the place, or further ahead. On the times you do have to go back, the solution are clear, and there's usually an easy game to get back. Again, the point of the game is to present you with a silly story and character interactions, and it does that very well!

[b][u]Conclusion[/u][/b]
I don't have anything else to say, honestly. I really, [i]really[/i] enjoyed the whole way through. It's on the short side, but it's certainly worth it. If you like Double Fine's games (the Stacking and Grim Fandango particularly coming to mind -- And Psychonauts for most people), give this one a go! I'm sure you won't be disappointed. 
Even if you don't... if the description sounds appealing, I still recommend it. It's just a very good game!

While the game is not particularly difficult, it has some tricky passages and minor puzzles. 13831701.review:
[i]Stick it to The Man![/i] è una piccola perla dell'universo dei giochi Indie che appartiene al genere dei [i]Platform Puzzle Game[/i].
La grafica e le meccaniche ricordano vagamente quelle di [i]Paper Mario[/i], mentre la trama è delineata da una nota di sarcasmo che farà sorridere per tutta la (purtroppo breve) durata del gioco. Questo, infatti, si può facilmente completare in qualche ora data la difficoltà molto semplice degli enigmi proposti, che per essere completati, servirà solo del buon senso senza doversi scervellare più di tanto. Tornando alla grafica, l'ho trovata molto piacevole e originale e il fatto che il mondo sia fatto interamente di carta ha reso possibile l'implementazione del taglia/incolla in qualunque ambito. L'altra meccanica degna di nota, che in combinazione del taglia/incolla rende questo gioco unico nel suo genere, è il fatto di poter leggere le menti delle altre persone per poter capire cosa desiderano e quindi avanzare nel gioco. Seppur il gioco sia molto ripetitivo, il principale motivo per cui si vorrà proseguire nel gioco è il voler vedere come il susseguirsi di determinate azioni possano rendere la storia molto assurda ed ironica. Infine, in alcuni frangenti, si dovrà fuggire da delle guardie incaricate di catturarvi (come in ogni singolo gioco) e il ciò comporterà giocare di stealth o d'astuzia usando i poteri in possesso nel gioco. Nella sua interezza il gioco propone spunti originali e graficamente deliziosi che lo rendono unico nel settore.

[b]Voto: 9/10[/b]

13814735.review:
Simple, refreshing and humorous. The mood is light, platforming is stress free and the puzzles are rather simple, designed to put a smile on your face, rather than pose serious problems. People looking for a more serious mental exercise should probably pass this one up.

The game has really excellent voice acting. Many other outspoken modern titles manage to do a lot less with a lot more resources in this regard, while SITTM characters are imbued with actual character thanks to the actors. This being said, some characters speak a bit slowly so they're king of a chore, however you'll promptly realize you can control voice pitch with A and D keys. Which provides even more fun potential.

I recommend not rushing through the chatter, there's fun to be had with the dialogue (which for the better part is actually monologue.)

Hadn't had any stability issues, the game ran perfect. The only thing worth mentioning is the fact it has an iffy resolution support and since my screen's native resolution wasn't on the list, I dialed it down a bit and turned on the windowed mode. Which worked out well enough.

I guess I'd rate this one with a solid eight out of ten.

13810353.review:
Clever point-and-click fetch game with platformer elements. Plagued by problems common to p&c games; puzzles with either nonsensiscal or painfully obvious combinations of items to overcome, much backtracking back and forh on your keycard/fetch quests. Very little thinking required on the player's part. Simply run all over the map and use everything on everything. Anything you can interact with is highlighted leaving all the guesswork out.

Still, a charming game with obvious LucasArts/Double Fine influences. The levels are small enough that the puzzling and platforming back and forth does not get too tedious. The voice-acting is lacking at times, but the quirkly humor and art style make up for it.

If you liked the characters and charm of Psychonauts, you'll probably like this game as well.  I really enjoyed the funny characters, which were brought to life by great art, animation, and voice acting.

At its heart, Stick it to the Man is an adventure game with mild 2D platforming.  Most of your time will be spent solving puzzles by reading people's minds, collecting items, and figuring out how to use them to progress.

13736073.review:
Initially the game struck me as stylistically reminiscent of Psychonauts, but the more I played the more I kept getting reminded of Rocko's Modern Life, so I guess if you take those two, mash 'em together, and then put them in the context of a 2.5D point'n'click (move'n'stick?) adventure, this is what you get.

The gameplay is relatively simple; you grab read people's thoughts, grab stickers, and then stick those stickers in the proper spots to solve the various puzzles, all while avoiding getting caught by the various thugs sprinkled as obstacles throughout the game. There are some platforming challenges involved, but calling them "challenges" is really stretching the definition of the word. The whole thing definitely leans on the casual side of the gaming fence, but what it lacks in challenge it more than makes up for with a great soundtrack, stylized and attractive visuals, and writing/voice acting that at the least got me to smirk for most of my playthrough if not made me laugh out loud a few times.

A short but thoroughly enjoyable experience and a game I'd highly recommend giving a shot.

12877020.review:
Every now and then I’ll encounter a game that completely flies under my radar due to the amount of triple-A titles that demand my attention. I was introduced to Stick it to the Man after a friend showed me his copy on PS4, and after watching a few minutes of gameplay I knew right away that this was an adventure that I needed to track down.

In most aspects, Stick it to the Man is heavily influenced by Double Fine studios, and the art, humor, and platforming style invokes Psychonauts heavily throughout. There are actually a few easter eggs sprinkled in the game that reference Double Fine (such as a stuffed doll of Double Fine’s double-headed logo), but it doesn’t feel as if this title is stealing too much from the larger company. I very much enjoyed the concept of the game, living in a sort-of shadow box world with cardboard cutouts and interactive stickers, and the level design is varied and unique. Game difficulty isn’t an issue, although I did encounter odd bugs once or twice which prevented me from making forward progress (namely, sticker mounting points would not immediately appear next to important characters or locations). Also, when several interaction points are clustered near each other, your controls can get squirrelly as the game attempts to snap to context-sensitive areas (and this happens quite frequently).

The story is nonsensical and lighthearted, which I found to be a refreshing change of pace with so many games recently sticking to dark and brooding or sardonic main characters. Ray, the protagonist, is very sweet and helpful to everyone he interacts with, including Ted, the goofy and forgetful alien taking residence in his brain. This isn’t an award-winning story, but it’s wholly entertaining for about five or six hours, though a second playthrough isn’t really needed, save for achievement cleanup.

Stick it to the Man is short and sweet, and I’m very happy that I picked up this platformer when I had the chance. Recommended for most – it’s often listed at a cheap price digitally and is worth a single playthrough.

One of the better indie games out there. An interesting title that does things differently.

What not to expect:
- combat
- platforming
- a challenge

What to expect:
- cool sound track (Jazz like I think)
- Surreal art style
- Funny story and dialogue
- An interesting game mechanic (you basically can mind read people, steal their thoughts, "stick" them somewhere else and use it to grab high ledges)
- logical "puzzles"

Synopsis: You are Ray, Ray has a spaghetti arm growing out of his head with which he can do the aforementioned things. Reading people's minds will unlock the "puzzles", which are mainly get A to B to progress. Sounds boring, but the challenge is not what makes the game appealing. It's the art style, the humour, the semi-professional voice acting and the chilled sound track.
It's definitely worth picking up for about 10 dollars or so and can be beaten in about 5-6 hours I'd say. There is NO replay value, however, so maybe you want to pick this up during a sale. I found it entertaining enough and got it via summer sale.

Definitely recommended, just for NOT being an indie platformer, FPS or roguelike game, which is apparently all the indie scene has to offer, which doesn't suck. Oh and some sim games I guess...

12592554.review:
78%

Stick it to the Man is being hailed as a "spiritual successor to Psychonauts", a title that I have a few problems with. Sure, it deals with similar subject material and has a similar design aesthetic, but that's like saying "EVE Online is a spiritual successor to Galaga". The games are barely similar, the matching artstyle is the closest you're going to get.

SITTM plays more like a graphic novel with limited adventure game puzzle solving mechanics. You'll get that nice rewarding feeling from putting the right item into the right slot, but the majority of your time will be spent patiently listening to every mind-reading audio file, regardless of whether or not the puzzle is already solved. You will feel a compulsive need to read EVERY mind you come across, even if it's unnecessary, and you probably should because there's an achievement for it. Ultimately, while having the game come to a stop every 30 seconds so you can read a new mind does indeed break good, natural gameplay flow into splintery pieces, I immediately forgive it. The game is never boring, and no amount of dialogue could stop be from being impressed by the beautiful design.

Well... I SAY that, but I never actually finished the game :/.

The game plays in 2.5D, and I have to say, I've played with better platforming controls. The protagonist can swing to designated areas and manipulate certain pieces of backdrop, but regular jumping to certin platforms is finnicky, and you will find yourself slipping off quite often if you didn't jump PERFECTLY.

I would have rated this game way lower, but it's rare to find a game that makes me laugh so damn hard. The game is genuinely enjoyable, and gets a high reccomendation.

12560347.review:
A very nice puzzle-platformer/adventure game hybrid with quite an enjoyable story and sense of humor.
It's basically 2D psychonauts in terms of writing, let's be honest. Both in the humor and the fact that the focus of the story is around brains. That's not a problem. I like psychonauts. It doesn't really rip off any elements or steal any jokes from the game, either, so it ends up working really well. Ray does sound quite a lot like Rasputin though. Which is fine.
The main gameplay is jumping around platforms, grabbing stuff with your magic spaghetti hand, solving puzzles, and avoiding enemies. There's not a whole lot of depth to it and the game ends up being rather short, but it doesn't ever feel repetitive either. The stealth segments are probably the weakest, since most of the time there's no reason to not just brute-force your way through them. The puzzles aren't too difficult as usually you're told exactly what you need and where, which is good since they'd be very adventure game-y puzzles otherwise. The weirdness of the scenarios actually adds to the variety and it's amusing to see just what the game decides to do next. The game also looks great and sounds great, the paper aesthetic is played with quite nicely and the music is pretty fitting for the tone and style. The only real downside is the length; while it makes for a pretty complete package, the $15 price tag may not be enough to justify the experience for everyone. Still, I'd definitely call this a great game.
